name: Core Abilities
content:
See the Renaissance Character Sheet.

Each character has three CORE ABILITIES: BODY, HEART and WITS. Each core ability has five skills that fall under its domain, as well as one virtue, one weakness and one state:

SKILLS represent actions that are generally useful in the course of adventuring. Any PC may use any skill at any time (if the GM deems it appropriate for the situation), but their chances of success are increased as they gain ranks in a given skill, up to a maximum of 5 ranks. Each rank adds one success die (d6) to your dice pool for checks made with that skill. If you have no ranks in a skill, you only roll a feat die (d12), with no success dice.

Each VIRTUE is a resource derived from its associated core ability. Its maximum is determined by that core abilityâ€™s score, and its current score changes over the course of gameplay, starting with the maximum.

Each virtue is countered by a WEAKNESS. Weaknesses represent vulnerabilities accumulated over the course of gameplay. Weaknesses only have a current score, no maximum, and start at zero.

When a weakness outweighs its associated virtue, the character is in a STATE. Each state applies a -1d penalty to all skills in its column, as well as a general penalty to all skill checks, which varies by state.


BODY

BODY represents a characterâ€™s physical ability and power.


SKILLS

AWE is used to impress or intimidate others with your appearance or with physical feats:  Strike an impressive posture. Hold a sword to a captiveâ€™s neck. List your accomplishments in a booming voice.

STRENGTH is used for physical actions that require brute force or sustained effort:  Swing a cudgel. Scale a high rampart. Flip a heavy cart. Break down a door. Chase a fleeing foe. Swim against the current.

DEXTERITY is used for physical actions that require finesse or a quick reaction:  Throw a dagger. Pick a lock. Dodge an explosion. Aim a bow. Cartwheel over a low wall. Grab a ledge as you begin to fall.

FORTITUDE is used to withstand physical hardships or discomfort:  Endure cold. Resist poison. Row a boat through the night. Press on through hunger and thirst. Survive the physical effects of a spell.

CRAFT is used to make or mend things by hand:  Set a trap. Build an improvised raft. Make camp in a defensive position. Mend a torn waterskin. Hammer a circlet into shape. Tie a complex knot.


ENDURANCE

ENDURANCE is a virtue that represents a characterâ€™s physical stamina. It is generally reduced by harm suffered in combat or strenuous activity and is restored through rest.

Your Endurance maximum is 5 times your BODY score:  For example, a character with a BODY score of 3 would have a maximum Endurance of 15. You start with a current Endurance score equal to your maximum.

When a character is reduced to 0 Endurance, they fall unconscious and wake up one hour later with 1 Endurance, unless they are in the Helpless state (see below).


LOAD

LOAD is a weakness that represents the weight and discomfort caused by the clothing, armor, weapons and equipment youâ€™re carrying.

Your current Load is equal to the weight you are carrying, in pounds, minus your maximum Endurance, minus your BODY score. The minimum for Load is 0 - you canâ€™t have a negative Load score.

Note that Load is measured moment-to-moment, so you could choose to drop a heavy pack or other weighty item to reduce your Load score in a pinch.


WEARY

WEARY is a state that represents when the weight and bulk of a characterâ€™s equipment begins to affect their performance.

When your Load score is equal to or greater than your current Endurance score, you are Weary.

While Weary, you take -1d to all BODY skill checks.


TWICE WEARY

If your Load equals or exceeds your maximum Endurance, you are TWICE WEARY: on ALL your skill checks (not just BODY), success die results of 3 or less donâ€™t count toward the total for the check. This is in addition to the effects of Weary.



HEART

HEART represents a characterâ€™s force of personality and spirit.


SKILLS

PERFORM is used to delight, enthrall or deceive others:  Sing a song. Cause a distraction. Convince the guard that you are someone youâ€™re not.

INSIGHT is used to perceive the feelings and motivations of others:  Read a room. See through a lie. Sense the merchantâ€™s ulterior motive.

COURTESY is used to engage your manners and say the right thing:  Introduce yourself to an important noble. Buy a drink for a potential ally. Ask a prying question delicately.

SPIRIT is used to call on your connection to magic and the supernatural:  Cast a spell. Resist a curse. Overcome fear. Commune with a deity.

AID is used to help, heal, guide or comfort others:  Mend a wound. Offer encouragement to an ally. Treat poison. Remind a leader of their purpose.


HOPE

HOPE is a virtue that represents a characterâ€™s reserve of spiritual fortitude and positivity. It is generally reduced when a player calls upon that reserve to push themselves and is restored through rest and time away from the adventuring life. The GM may also award Hope at their discretion.

Your Hope maximum is 3 times your HEART score. For example, a character with a HEART score of 3 would have a maximum Hope of 9. You start with a current Hope score equal to your maximum.

A hopeful character can keep going when physically stronger heroes have already succumbed to despair. At any time, before making a skill check, a player may choose to spend 1 Hope to gain an additional success die on the roll. You can only do this once per skill check. When you spend Hope, take a moment to describe what your character is drawing on to push through.

When a character is reduced to 0 Hope, they are spiritually drained and cannot push themselves beyond their limits - you cannot go below 0 Hope to gain an additional success die on a skill check.


SHADOW

SHADOW is a weakness that represents a characterâ€™s accumulated sense of fear, dread and despair. It starts at 0 and is generally gained by encountering frightful or evil creatures, figures and places. The GM may also assign Shadow to a character who commits a cruel, deceptive or cowardly act.

At the GMâ€™s discretion, you may have an opportunity to make a skill check to resist gaining Shadow.

Shadow is generally reduced by spending time mending spiritual hurt, overcoming fears, or visiting a place of spiritual power or personal significance.


MISERABLE

MISERABLE is a state that represents a characterâ€™s shaken will or lost determination to fight.

When your Shadow score is equal to or greater than your current Hope score, you are Miserable.

While Miserable, you take -1d to all HEART skill checks.


TWICE MISERABLE

If your Shadow equals or exceeds your maximum Endurance, you are TWICE MISERABLE: on ALL your skill checks (not just HEART), a Morte ðŸ’€ on a feat die means the check automatically fails, regardless of the total. This is in addition to the effects of Miserable.


WITS

WITS represents a characterâ€™s intellect and cleverness.


SKILLS

PERSUADE is used to change the minds of others through rhetoric or compromise:  Convince a regent that your quest aligns with their interests. Make an offer to recruit a potential ally. Calm an angry mob by explaining yourself.

AWARENESS is used to perceive your surroundings through your senses:  Spy an ambush along a road. Notice the dirt under the captainâ€™s fingernails. Hear a conversation through a door. Smell faint smoke.

STEALTH is used to avoid detection or act discreetly:  Sneak past the guards. Pick the magistrateâ€™s pocket. Hide in a tree. Blend into a crowd. Leave no trace as you travel.

LORE is used to recall knowledge and experience:  Remember details about a town you once visited. Call upon your years spent studying texts in the temple. Draw upon wisdom gained navigating the wilderness.

RIDDLE is used for deduction and reasoning:  Look for clues in a room. Ponder a cryptic poem. Make connections between the wizardâ€™s warning and the warlordâ€™s threat.


DEFENSE

DEFENSE is a virtue that represents a characterâ€™s ability to dodge attacks through skill or cunning. It can also be augmented by armor and various effects.

Your Defense maximum is equal to 10 plus your WITS score. For example, a character with a WITS score of 3 would have a maximum Defense of 13. You start with a current Defense score equal to your maximum.

When a character is reduced to 0 Defense, they offer no resistance to attacks.


INJURY

INJURY is a weakness that represents the wounds a character has sustained and is currently suffering from.

Injury starts at 0 and generally increases through combat and other adventuring mishaps. It is generally reduced by lengthy rest and skilled healing. See the Combat section for more information about sustaining Injury.


HELPLESS

HELPLESS is a state that represents when a characterâ€™s wounds leave them at the mercy of their foes. When your Injury score is equal to or greater than your Defense score, you are Helpless.

While Helpless, you take -1d to all WITS skill checks, and you cannot choose to take a condition instead of taking Injury (see Conditions below and Resisting Injury in the Combat section).


TWICE HELPLESS

If your Injury equals or exceeds your maximum Defense, you are TWICE HELPLESS:  In addition to the effects of Helpless, attacks against you automatically succeed, and if your Endurance is or is reduced to 0, you are dying. See Knockouts & Dying in the Combat section.
